title: Quiz 1: Internet and Network Fundamentals
description: Test your knowledge of Internet basics, network architecture, and core networking concepts

questions.question: What is the Internet, and what role do protocols play in it?
questions.hint:
Approach:

1.Define what the Internet is at a high level
2.Describe its physical components (devices, links, switches)
3.Explain what protocols are and their purpose
4.Give examples of common protocols and their functions
  • Key concepts to cover: Network of networks, hosts/end systems, packet switches, communication rules
  • Examples: HTTP, SMTP, TCP/IP, DNS
questions.answer: The Internet is a global network of interconnected computer networks that enables communication and information sharing worldwide. It consists of billions of computing devices (hosts/end systems) connected through various types of links and packet switches (routers and link-layer switches). Protocols play a crucial role as they define the format, order of messages sent and received among network entities, and the actions taken on message transmission and receipt. They provide the rules and conventions that enable different devices and software to communicate effectively. Examples include HTTP for web browsing, SMTP for email, TCP/IP for reliable data transmission, etc.

questions.question: What is the network edge, and what are its components?
questions.hint:
Network Edge Approach:

1.Define what the network edge represents in network architecture
2.Identify the main components that make up the edge
3.Distinguish between end systems and access methods
  • Key components: End systems/hosts, Access networks, Physical media
  • Think about: Where users interact with the network vs. the core infrastructure
questions.answer: The network edge consists of the end systems (hosts) that are connected to the Internet. These are the devices where applications run and where users interact with the network. Components include: End systems/hosts (computers, smartphones, servers, IoT devices), Access networks (residential access like DSL/cable/fiber, institutional access like Ethernet/WiFi, mobile access like 4G/5G), Physical media (guided media like fiber, coax, twisted pair; unguided media like wireless)

questions.question: What is the difference between a client and a server in networking?
questions.hint:
Client-Server Architecture:

1.Define what a client does in network communication
2.Define what a server does in network communication
3.Explain the key differences in behavior and roles
  • Client behavior: Initiates requests, seeks services
  • Server behavior: Waits for requests, provides services
  • Consider: Which one starts communication? Which one responds?
questions.answer: CLIENT: A program or device that requests services from another program or device. It initiates communication by sending requests. SERVER: A program or device that provides services to clients. It waits for and responds to requests from clients. Key differences: Clients initiate communication; servers wait for requests. Servers typically run continuously; clients connect as needed. A single server can serve multiple clients simultaneously. The same device can act as both client and server for different services.

questions.question: What is the function of the network core in the Internet?
questions.hint:
Network Core Functions:

1.Describe the physical structure of the network core
2.Explain the main function: moving data between sources and destinations
3.List the key processes involved in data forwarding
  • Components: Routers, switches, interconnected mesh
  • Key functions: Packet switching, routing, forwarding
  • Goal: Reliable data delivery between end systems
questions.answer: The network core is the mesh of interconnected routers and switches that forward packets from source to destination. Its main functions include: Packet switching: Breaking data into packets and forwarding them independently, Routing: Determining the best path for packets to reach their destination, Forwarding: Moving packets from input links to appropriate output links, Managing network traffic and congestion, Providing redundancy and fault tolerance through multiple paths

questions.question: What is packet switching, and why is it used?
questions.hint:
Packet Switching Fundamentals:

1.Define how packet switching works (break data into packets)
2.Explain how packets are forwarded independently
3.List the advantages over circuit switching
  • Key concept: Data broken into small units with addressing info
  • Benefits: Efficient resource sharing, fault tolerance, flexibility
  • Why used: Better for bursty traffic, cost-effective
questions.answer: Packet switching is a method of data transmission where messages are broken into small units called packets, each containing destination address and sequence information. Each packet is forwarded independently through the network. Why it's used: Efficient resource sharing (no dedicated circuits needed), Better fault tolerance (alternative paths available), More flexible and scalable than circuit switching, Allows statistical multiplexing of resources, Cost-effective for bursty data traffic

questions.question: How does packet switching differ from circuit switching?
questions.hint:
Switching Method Comparison:

1.Describe circuit switching characteristics (dedicated path)
2.Describe packet switching characteristics (shared resources)
3.Compare advantages and use cases for each
  • Circuit switching: Dedicated connection, guaranteed resources, constant delay
  • Packet switching: Shared resources, statistical multiplexing, variable delay
  • Key difference: Resource reservation vs. resource sharing
questions.answer: CIRCUIT SWITCHING: Establishes dedicated end-to-end connection before communication, Resources reserved for entire call duration, Guaranteed bandwidth and performance, Used in traditional telephone networks, More suitable for continuous, constant-rate traffic. PACKET SWITCHING: No dedicated path; packets forwarded independently, Resources shared among users (statistical multiplexing), Variable delay and throughput, More efficient for bursty traffic, Better resource utilization

questions.question: What are the types of delays in a network?
questions.hint:
Network Delay Components:

1.Think about what happens when a packet travels through a router
2.Consider the sequence: Arrival → Processing → Queuing → Transmission → Propagation
3.For each step, identify the time delay
  • Processing: Time to examine packet and decide where to send it
  • Queueing: Time waiting in line for transmission
  • Transmission: Time to push bits onto the wire (L/R)
  • Propagation: Time for signal to travel the physical distance (d/s)
questions.answer: Four main types of delays: 1. PROCESSING DELAY: Time to examine packet header, check for errors, and determine output link, 2. QUEUEING DELAY: Time spent waiting in output queue before transmission, 3. TRANSMISSION DELAY: Time to push all packet bits onto the link (L/R), 4. PROPAGATION DELAY: Time for signal to travel from source to destination (d/s). Total nodal delay = Processing + Queueing + Transmission + Propagation

questions.question: What is packet loss, and what causes it?
questions.hint:
Packet Loss Analysis:

1.Define what packet loss means in networking
2.Identify the main causes of packet loss
3.Consider both hardware and network congestion factors
  • Definition: Packets fail to reach their destination
  • Main causes: Buffer overflow, network congestion, hardware failures
  • Think about: What happens when routers get overloaded?
questions.answer: Packet loss occurs when packets are dropped/discarded in the network and fail to reach their destination. Causes: Buffer overflow: Queues become full, arriving packets are dropped, Network congestion: Too much traffic exceeds link capacity, Hardware failures: Router/switch malfunctions, Transmission errors: Corrupted packets are discarded, Network configuration issues

questions.question: What is throughput in networking?
questions.hint:
Throughput vs Bandwidth:

1.Define throughput as actual data transfer rate achieved
2.Distinguish between instantaneous and average throughput
3.Explain factors that limit throughput
  • Key concept: Actual rate of successful data transmission
  • Units: Bits per second (bps), Mbps, Gbps
  • Limitation: Throughput ≤ Bandwidth due to bottlenecks
questions.answer: Throughput is the actual rate at which data is successfully transmitted between source and destination, measured in bits per second (bps). Types: INSTANTANEOUS THROUGHPUT: Rate at any given instant, AVERAGE THROUGHPUT: Average rate over longer time period, END-TO-END THROUGHPUT: Limited by bottleneck link (minimum capacity link in path). Throughput ≤ Bandwidth due to factors like congestion, protocol overhead, and network conditions.

questions.question: Why is layering used in network architecture?
questions.hint:
Network Layering Benefits:

1.Think about software engineering principles
2.Consider how layers hide complexity from each other
3.List the advantages for development and maintenance
  • Key benefits: Modularity, abstraction, interoperability
  • Development advantages: Independent development, reusability
  • Maintenance: Changes in one layer don't affect others
questions.answer: Layering provides several benefits: MODULARITY: Each layer focuses on specific functions, ABSTRACTION: Lower layers hide complexity from upper layers, INTEROPERABILITY: Standardized interfaces enable different implementations, MAINTAINABILITY: Changes in one layer don't affect others, REUSABILITY: Layers can be reused across different applications, DISTRIBUTED DEVELOPMENT: Different teams can work on different layers

questions.question: Which of the following descriptions correspond to a "services" view of the Internet? Select one or more correct answers. [Hint: more than one answer is correct]
questions.hint:
Services vs. Nuts-and-Bolts View:

1.Think about the Internet from a user's perspective
2.Consider what the Internet enables rather than how it works
3.Focus on applications and user experiences
  • Services view: What can you DO with the Internet?
  • Not services view: Technical details about hardware and protocols
options: A. A platform for building network applications.

B. A collection of hardware and software components executing protocols that define the format and the order of messages exchanged between two or more communicating entities, as well as the actions taken on the transmission and/or receipt of a message or other event.
C. A collection of billions of computing devices, and packet switches interconnected by links.
D. A place I go for information, entertainment, and to communicate with people.

questions.question: Which of the following human scenarios involve a protocol? (recall: "Protocols define the format, order of messages sent and received among network entities, and actions taken on message transmission, receipt") Select one or more correct answers. [Hint: more than one answer is correct]
questions.hint:
Human Protocol Analysis:

1.Apply the protocol definition to human interactions
2.Look for structured message exchange patterns
3.Identify scenarios with defined rules and responses
  • Protocol elements: Format, order, actions on transmission/receipt
  • Look for: Back-and-forth communication with rules
  • Not protocols: One-way activities or unstructured interactions
options: A. Two people introducing themselves to each other.
B. A person reading a book.
C. One person asking, and getting, the time to/from another person.

E. A student raising her/his hand to ask a really insightful question, followed by the teaching acknowledging the student, listening carefully to the question, and responding with a clear, insightful answer. And then thanking the student for the question, since teachers love to get questions.

questions.question: Which of the following physical layer technologies has the highest transmission rate and lowest bit error rate in practice?
questions.hint:
Physical Media Comparison:

1.Consider the fundamental properties of each medium
2.Think about which medium is least susceptible to interference
3.Consider both speed and reliability factors
  • Key factors: Transmission rate (speed) and bit error rate (reliability)
  • Think about: Guided vs. unguided media, interference susceptibility
  • Modern networks: What do high-speed networks use for backbone connections?

questions.question: Write distinction between routing versus forwarding.
questions.hint:
Routing vs Forwarding:

1.Define routing as the network-wide path determination process
2.Define forwarding as the local packet movement at each router
3.Compare their scope, timeframe, and functions
  • Routing: Control plane, creates tables, network-wide, slower timescale
  • Forwarding: Data plane, uses tables, local action, fast timescale
  • Analogy: Routing = planning route, Forwarding = following directions
questions.answer: ROUTING: Network-wide process that determines end-to-end paths, Creates and maintains routing tables/forwarding tables, Uses routing algorithms (e.g., OSPF, BGP), Operates on longer timescales, Control plane function. FORWARDING: Local action at each router, Moves packets from input link to appropriate output link, Uses forwarding table created by routing process, Operates on packet timescales (nanoseconds), Data plane function

questions.question: Consider the circuit-switched network shown in the figure below, with four circuit switches A, B, C, and D. Suppose there are 20 circuits between A and B, 19 circuits between B and C, 15 circuits between C and D, and 16 circuits between D and A. What is the maximum number of connections that can be ongoing in the network at any one time?
questions.hint:
Circuit Switching Approach:

1.Understand that in circuit switching, each connection needs a dedicated circuit
2.Each link can handle multiple simultaneous connections up to its circuit capacity
3.The maximum connections = sum of all link capacities
Total connections = Circuits(A-B) + Circuits(B-C) + Circuits(C-D) + Circuits(D-A)
  • Key insight: Unlike packet switching, circuit switching reserves dedicated paths
  • Each circuit can carry one connection simultaneously

questions.question: Consider a scenario in which 5 users are being multiplexed over a 10 Mbps channel. Under the following scenarios, determine whether circuit switching, packet switching, or neither is better suited for the situation.
questions.hint:
Circuit vs Packet Switching Analysis:

1.For Circuit Switching: Check if total demand ≤ channel capacity
Total demand = Number of users × Rate per user
2.For Packet Switching: Check if peak rate fits and average utilization is reasonable
3.Compare: Constant rate → Circuit; Bursty traffic → Packet
  • Circuit switching: Dedicated bandwidth, works if total ≤ capacity
  • Packet switching: Statistical multiplexing, handles bursts better
  • Neither: When requirements exceed capacity fundamentally

parts.question: Each user generates traffic at an average rate of 2.1 Mbps, generating traffic at a rate of 15 Mbps when transmitting
parts.answer: Neither - Total demand (5 × 2.1 = 10.5 Mbps) exceeds capacity for circuit switching, and peak rate (15 Mbps) exceeds capacity for packet switching

parts.question: Each user generates traffic at an average rate of 2 Mbps, and always transmits at a rate of 2 Mbps when active
parts.answer: Circuit switching - Total demand (5 × 2 = 10 Mbps) exactly equals capacity, and constant rate suits circuit switching

parts.question: Each user generates traffic at an average rate of 0.21 Mbps, generating traffic at a rate of 15 Mbps when transmitting
parts.answer: Packet switching - Low average rate (5 × 0.21 = 1.05 Mbps total) allows statistical multiplexing to handle bursty 15 Mbps peaks

questions.question: Match each network delay description with its correct type of delay:
questions.hint:
Network Delay Types:

1.Think about the sequence of events when a packet arrives at a router
2.Consider what happens: examine → wait → transmit → travel
3.Match each description to its corresponding delay type
  • Processing: Router examines and decides
  • Queueing: Waiting in buffers
  • Transmission: Pushing bits onto link (L/R)
  • Propagation: Signal travel time (d/s)

items.description: Time needed to perform an integrity check, look up packet information in a local table, and move the packet from an input link to an output link in a router.
Time spent waiting in packet buffers for link transmission due to congestion or scheduling.
Time spent transmitting the packet's bits into the link (i.e., from sender's buffer onto the wire).
Time needed for bits to physically propagate through the transmission medium from one end of a link to the other.

questions.question: Consider the scenario shown below, with four different servers connected to four different clients over four three-hop paths. The four pairs share a common middle hop with a transmission capacity of R = 300 Mbps. The four links from the servers to the shared link have a transmission capacity of RS = 50 Mbps. Each of the four links from the shared middle link to a client has a transmission capacity of RC = 90 Mbps. What is the maximum achievable end-end throughput (an integer value, in Mbps) for each of four client-to-server pairs, assuming that the middle link is fairly shared (divides its transmission rate equally) and all servers are trying to send at their maximum rate?
questions.hint:
Throughput Analysis Approach:

1.Identify all link capacities in the path: Server→Middle→Client
2.Calculate middle link capacity per flow: Total middle capacity ÷ Number of flows
3.Find the bottleneck: minimum capacity among all hops
Bottleneck = min(Server_capacity, Middle_per_flow, Client_capacity)
4.The bottleneck determines maximum throughput
  • Server links: RS = 50 Mbps each
  • Middle link per flow: R/4 = 300/4 = 75 Mbps
  • Client links: RC = 90 Mbps each
questions.answer: 50 Mbps - The bottleneck is the server links at 50 Mbps each. Middle link capacity (300/4 = 75 Mbps per flow) and client links (90 Mbps) are higher.

questions.question: Match each Internet layer with the correct unit of data that is exchanged among protocol entities at that layer.
questions.hint:
Internet Layer Data Units:

1.Think about what each layer handles from top to bottom
2.Consider the abstraction level at each layer
3.Remember: higher layers = bigger units, lower layers = smaller units
  • Application: Complete user messages
  • Transport: End-to-end delivery units
  • Network: Routing units
  • Link: Hop-by-hop units
  • Physical: Basic electrical signals

questions.question: Consider the circuit-switched network shown in the figure below, with circuit switches A, B, C, and D. Suppose there are 13 circuits between A and B, 19 circuits between B and C, 15 circuits between C and D, and 17 circuits between D and A.
questions.hint:
Circuit Switching with Constraints:

1.For max connections: Add all link capacities
2.For overload: Consider what happens when capacity is exceeded
3.For constrained routing: Find bottleneck links for each path
4.For accommodation: Check if demand ≤ path capacity
  • Total capacity: Sum of all individual link capacities
  • Path constraints: Minimum capacity along the path
  • Clockwise paths: A→B→C, B→C→D, etc.

parts.question: What is the maximum number of connections that can be ongoing in the network at any one time?
parts.answer: 64 (sum of all circuits: 13 + 19 + 15 + 17 = 64)

parts.question: Suppose that these maximum number of connections are all ongoing. What happens when another call connection request arrives to the network, will it be accepted? Answer Yes or No
parts.answer: No - All circuits are already in use

parts.question: Suppose that every connection requires 2 consecutive hops, and calls are connected clockwise. For example, a connection can go from A to C, from B to D, from C to A, and from D to B. With these constraints, what is the maximum number of connections that can be ongoing in the network at any one time?
parts.answer: 28 (A to C: min(13,19) = 13 connections, B to D: min(19,15) = 15 connections. Total: 13 + 15 = 28)

parts.question: Suppose that 11 connections are needed from A to C, and 13 connections are needed from B to D. Can we route these calls through the four links to accommodate all 24 connections? Answer Yes or No
parts.answer: Yes - A to C needs 11 ≤ 13 (A-B capacity), B to D needs 13 ≤ 15 (C-D capacity). Both can be accommodated.

1.2: no - all circuits are already in use

questions.question: Consider the two scenarios below: A circuit-switching scenario in which Ncs users, each requiring a bandwidth of 20 Mbps, must share a link of capacity 100 Mbps. A packet-switching scenario with Nps users sharing a 100 Mbps link, where each user again requires 20 Mbps when transmitting, but only needs to transmit 20 percent of the time.

parts.question: When circuit switching is used, what is the maximum number of users that can be supported?
parts.answer: 5 users (100 Mbps ÷ 20 Mbps per user = 5)

parts.question: Suppose packet switching is used. If there are 9 packet-switching users, can this many users be supported under circuit-switching? Yes or No.
parts.answer: No - 9 users would need 9 × 20 = 180 Mbps, which exceeds the 100 Mbps capacity

parts.question: Suppose packet switching is used. What is the probability that a given (specific) user is transmitting, and the remaining users are not transmitting?
parts.answer: 0.034 - P(one transmitting) × P(8 not transmitting) = 0.20 × (0.80)^8 ≈ 0.034

parts.question: When one user is transmitting, what fraction of the link capacity will be used by this user? Write your answer as a decimal.

questions.question: Consider the store-and-forward transmission analogy with cars in a caravan being serviced at a toll booth. Suppose the caravan has 20 cars, and that the tollbooth services (transmits) a car at a rate of one car per 2 seconds. Once receiving service, a car proceeds to the next tollbooth, which is 200 kilometers away at a rate of 10 kilometers per second. The entire caravan must be stored at the tollbooth before the first car can begin driving towards the next tollbooth.

parts.question: Once a car enters service at the tollbooth, how long does it take until it leaves service?
parts.answer: 2 seconds - Given service rate is one car per 2 seconds

parts.question: How long does it take for the entire caravan to receive service at the tollbooth (time from when the first car enters service until the last car leaves the tollbooth)?
parts.answer: 40 seconds - 20 cars × 2 seconds/car = 40 seconds

parts.question: Once the first car leaves the tollbooth, how long does it take until it arrives at the next tollbooth?
parts.answer: 20 seconds - 200 km ÷ 10 km/s = 20 seconds

parts.question: Once the last car leaves the tollbooth, how long does it take until it arrives at the next tollbooth?
parts.answer: 20 seconds - Same propagation delay applies to all cars

parts.question: Are there ever two cars in service at the same time, one at the first toll booth and one at the second toll booth? Answer Yes or No
parts.answer: No - Store-and-forward requires entire caravan to finish at first booth before starting at second

parts.question: Are there ever zero cars in service at the same time, i.e., the caravan has finished at the first tollbooth but not yet arrived at the second tollbooth? Answer Yes or No
parts.answer: Yes - During the 20-second propagation delay between tollbooths

questions.question: Consider a single router transmitting packets, each of length L bits, over a single link with transmission rate R Mbps. Suppose that the packet length is L = 8000 bits, and that the link transmission rate is R = 1 Mbps.

parts.question: What is the transmission delay?
parts.answer: 0.008 seconds - L/R = 8000 bits ÷ 1×10^6 bps = 0.008 seconds (8 milliseconds)

parts.question: What is the maximum number of packets per second that can be transmitted by this link?
parts.answer: 125 packets/sec - R/L = 1×10^6 bps ÷ 8000 bits/packet = 125 packets/sec

questions.hint:
Transmission Delay Calculations:

1.For transmission delay: Use the formula
Transmission Delay = L/R (packet length / transmission rate)
2.For maximum packets per second: Think about how many packets fit in one second
Max packets/sec = R/L (transmission rate / packet length)
  • Units matter: Convert Mbps to bps (multiply by 10^6)
  • L = 8000 bits, R = 1 Mbps = 1×10^6 bps

questions.question: Consider the queuing delay in a router buffer, where the packet experiences a delay as it waits to be transmitted onto the link. Assume a constant transmission rate of R = 800000 bps, a constant packet-length L = 3900 bits, and a is the average rate of packets/second. Traffic intensity I = La/R, and the queuing delay is calculated as I(L/R)(1 - I) for I < 1.
questions.hint:
Queuing Delay Analysis:

1.For variability: Consider if real network traffic is constant or bursty
2.For buffer analysis: Compare arriving packets vs buffer capacity
3.Remember: Drops occur only when arrivals exceed buffer size
  • Real traffic: Bursty and unpredictable, causing delay variations
  • Buffer capacity: Maximum packets that can be stored
  • Drop condition: When arrivals > buffer capacity

parts.question: In practice, does the queuing delay tend to vary a lot? Answer with Yes or No
parts.answer: Yes - Because network traffic is often bursty and unpredictable, causing fluctuations in the number of packets waiting in the queue.

parts.question: If the buffer has a maximum size of 899 packets, how many of the 800 packets would be dropped upon arrival?
parts.answer: 0 - The buffer has a maximum capacity of 899 packets, and only 800 packets are arriving. Since the number of arriving packets is less than the buffer's maximum size, all of them can be accommodated without any being dropped.

questions.question: Computing end-end delay (transmission and propagation delay). Consider the figure below, with three links, each with the specified transmission rate and link length.
questions.hint:
End-to-End Delay Calculation:

1.Calculate transmission delay: T_trans = L/R (packet size / transmission rate)
2.Calculate propagation delay: T_prop = d/s (distance / speed of light)
3.Total delay = sum of all transmission + propagation delays
  • Transmission delay: Time to push all bits onto link
  • Propagation delay: Time for signal to travel the link
  • Speed of light: 3×10⁸ m/s

parts.question: Assume the length of a packet is 16000 bits. The speed of light propagation delay on each link is 3x10^8 m/sec. Round your answer to two decimals after leading zeros.
parts.answer: 0.0016 seconds

parts.question: What is the propagation delay of link 1?
parts.answer: 0.00001 seconds

questions.question: Consider the scenario shown below, with four different servers connected to four different clients over four three-hop paths. The four pairs share a common middle hop with a transmission capacity of R = 200 Mbps. The four links from the servers to the shared link have a transmission capacity of RS = 70 Mbps. Each of the four links from the shared middle link to a client has a transmission capacity of RC = 20 Mbps. What is the maximum achievable end-end throughput (in Mbps) for each of four client-to-server pairs, assuming that the middle link is fairly shared (divides its transmission rate equally)?
questions.hint:
Throughput Bottleneck Analysis:

1.Identify all link capacities in the path
2.For shared links: divide capacity by number of flows
3.Find the minimum capacity (bottleneck) in the path
  • Server links: 70 Mbps each
  • Middle link (shared): 200/4 = 50 Mbps per flow
  • Client links: 20 Mbps each
  • Bottleneck: Minimum of these three values
questions.answer: 20 Mbps - The bottleneck is the client links at 20 Mbps each. The middle link capacity (200/4 = 50 Mbps per flow) and server links (70 Mbps) are higher.
